[1]This is Harvey Milk speaking on Friday November 18th. This is to be played only in the event of my death by assassination... REVEAL: HARVEY MILK, 48, sitting at his kitchen table in a cluttered San Francisco apartment. 
[2]During one of the early campaigns, I started opening my speeches with the same line and it sort of became my signature... 
[3]Hello, I'm Harvey Milk, and I'm here to recruit you. 
[4]If I was speaking to a slightly hostile or mostly straight audience, I'd try to break the tension with a joke... 
[5]I know, I know, I'm not what you were expecting, but I left my high heels at home. Harvey gets a LAUGH from the AUDIENCE.     2. 
[6]I fully realize that a person who stands for what I stand for - an activist, a gay activist - becomes the target or potential target for a person who is insecure, terrified, afraid or very disturbed themselves... 
[7]Knowing that I could be assassinated at any moment, I feel it's important that some people should understand my thoughts. I think that--  I wish I had time to explain everything I did. Almost everything that was done was done with an eye on the gay movement. 
[8]Hey. I'm Harvey. 
[9]Today's my birthday.  No, today is actually my birthday. Well, tonight. At midnight. 
[10]And, believe it or not, I don't have any plans. People took me out after work... 
[11]The Great American Insurance Company. I'm part of the big, evil, corporate establishment that, let me guess, you think is the cause of every evil thing in the world from Vietnam to diaper rash. 
[12]So... You're not going to let me celebrate my birthday all by myself are you? 
[13]Well then, I'm in luck. 
[14]Because I'm still thirty-nine...  And it's only eleven-fifteen. 
[15]Where are you from? 
[16]Well, this isn't Jackson, but you still can't respond to every strange man you meet on a subway platform. It's too dangerous. 
[17]There's nothing tougher than a New York City cop. They're arrogant, and they're everywhere. I'll show you the cruising spots, if you want, if you promise you'll be careful... little Scottie-san. 
[18]No. This is just... plain old me. 
[19]I'm just discreet. I know a lot of people here. If they found out, I could lose my job. 
[20]I need a change. 
[21]Forty years old and I haven't done a thing I'm proud of. 
[22]No. Don't you worry. I won't make it to fifty. Scott distracts him, playful, like a newlywed at a wedding, he rubs a slice of pie in Harvey's face. Harvey reacts. Wipes the pie from his eye, and tackles his young, frisky new lover. They kiss. The mess getting everywhere. Harvey brushes it out of Scott's hair.

[24]In those days, San Francisco was the place where everyone wanted to go... To drop out... To fall in love... 
[25]But by 1972, The Haight was boarded up. Crime-filled. Drug-filled. The new place for us refugees was this run down Irish Catholic neighborhood in Eureka Valley. Six blocks square... The Castro.
